metadata.description: Dataset for Caption-Prompt-Judge framework for agricultural pest diagnosis
Dataset for Caption-Prompt-Judge framework for agricultural pest diagnosis

data.image_caption: Plant: cereal or other C4 grass (strap‑leaf cereal). Symptoms: numerous discrete 2–8 mm irregular–oval lesions concentrated mid‑blade; tan to light‑brown centers with narrower darker brown/reddish margins, some centers sunken/eroded and a few with split, pustule‑like eruptions; faint chlorosis surrounds lesions. Extent/severity: moderate, ~20–30% of the visible leaf area affected with a mix of active and older necrotic spots; veins and margins intact, no systemic wilting. Likely causes: fungal leaf‑spot pathogens (Cercospora, Bipolaris/Exserohilum group) or less commonly bacterial leaf spot; pustules suggest active sporulation. Next steps: take close‑ups and underside photos, collect samples for microscopy/culture/PCR, record recent weather and management, and scout incidence. Management: sanitation and residue management, improve airflow, use resistant hybrids and, if confirmed fungal and disease is progressing, apply labeled foliar fungicides (rotate FRAC groups); consider copper only if bacterial confirmation.
data.question: What measures can be taken to control Rice Blast?
data.answer:
(1) Select 2-3 locally resistant varieties, such as Zao 58, Xiangzaoxian 3, 21, 22, 86-44, 87-156, Wandao 61, Ganzhao 39, 42, 41, Boyouzan 19, Zhongyouzao 81, Zhusi 2, Peiliangyou 288, Huaxianzhan, and Shanyou 77 for early rice. For mid-season rice: Qidaozhan 1, Qixiuzhan 3, Peizashanqing, Sanpeizhan 1, Dianyinlujing 1, Ningjing 17, Ningnuo 4, Yangfuxian 2, Shengyou 2, Yangdao 2, 4, Dongxun 101, Dongnong 419, Qiyou 7, Jia 45, Xiushui 1067, Wandao 28, 32, 34, 36, 59, Shanyou 89, Teyou 689, Shanyou 397, Shanyouduoxi 1, Mancang 515, Quannong 3, Jinyou 63, Shanyouduoxi 1. For late rice: Xiushui 644, Yuanjing 4, Jin 308, Jingdaoxuan 1, Jijin 15, Huajing 45, Liao 244, Shen 9017, Gangyou 22, Bijing 37, Dianzhajing 2, Gangyou 2, Dianxian 13, 14, 40, Ningjing 15, 16. For drought-resistant varieties, choose Lin 3, Lin 5, Jing 31119, China 91. For dry direct seeding, use Zhengzhou Early Jing, Zhonghua 8.
(2) Use disease-free fields for seed collection, treat infected straw, and eliminate pathogen sources. Use soil disinfectants.
(3) Seed treatment: Soak seeds in 56℃ hot water for 5 minutes. Use 10% 401 antibacterial agent 1000 times solution or 80% 402 antibacterial agent (pyrimidine nucleoside antibiotics) 2000 times solution, or 70% methyl thiophanate 1000 times solution for 2 days. Alternatively, use 1% lime water for 6 days at 10-15℃, or 1-2 days at 20-25℃, with lime water 15cm above the seeds. Let stand, rinse 3-4 times with clean water. Soak seeds in 2% formalin for 20-30 minutes, then cover with a film for 3 hours.
(4) Use disease-free fields for seed collection, treat infected straw, and eliminate pathogen sources. Use soil disinfectants.
(5) Strengthen fertilizer and water management. Scientific management of fertilizer and water can improve environmental conditions, control pathogen reproduction and infection, promote healthy rice growth, and enhance disease resistance for stable and high yields. Apply nitrogen, phosphorus, and potassium in balance, combining base fertilizer, organic fertilizer, and chemical fertilizer, with appropriate use of silicon fertilizers (e.g., plant ash, slag, kiln ash potassium fertilizer). Apply sufficient potassium fertilizer, early topdressing, and appropriate mid-term fertilization based on crop and field conditions. Mixed application of silicon and magnesium fertilizers can significantly reduce disease incidence. Apply appropriate amounts of green manure, lime to promote decomposition, and neutralize acidity. In cold immersion fields, increase phosphate fertilizer application.
(6) Rotate fungicides due to the unique resistance of rice blast pathogen. Common fungicides like Jinggangmycin, Chunlei mycin, tricyclazole, methyl thiophanate, blastil, and Fuji No.1 should be alternated. For prevention and early disease: spray diluted 800-1200 times. For mid to late disease: spray diluted 800-1000 times. For severe cases: spray 20% tricyclazole 500 times solution, followed by specific fungicides like Menshen 800 times solution after 7 days. Use tebuconazole for leaf blast in early to mid-July, applying 25% fluopicolide-tebuconazole 0.75-0.9L/ha or 45% tebuconazole 0.42-0.5L/ha, spraying twice weekly. For neck blast, spray at the beginning and full heading stages. Use the same dosage as for leaf blast.
data.reasoning: The caption provides strong, specific symptom detail (leaf shape, lesion size, color, margins, distribution, percent area affected, and disease stage), which is highly useful for diagnosis. However, it omits the plant species and does not suggest a likely disease or differential diagnoses, limiting immediate diagnostic value and management guidance.
data.suggestions: Add the host plant species (e.g., maize, wheat, grass) and, if possible, propose likely causes or a differential (e.g., bacterial/necrotic leaf spot, fungal leaf spot, rust/pustular disease). Note diagnostic details such as pustule color/spore mass, symptoms on the leaf underside, lesion progression/timeline, and whether multiple leaves/plants are affected. Recommend next steps: take close-up and underside photos, collect samples for microscopy/culture or lab confirmation, record recent weather and crop management, and include preliminary management options (sanitation, resistant varieties, targeted fungicides/bactericides) tailored to suspected pathogens.
data.original_caption: The photographed single strap-shaped leaf is long and narrow with pronounced parallel veins. Numerous discrete lesions are scattered along the blade, concentrated toward the mid-section. Lesions are roughly 2–8 mm, irregular to oval, with tan to light-brown centers and narrower darker-brown or reddish margins; some centers appear sunken or eroded. Surrounding tissue shows faint chlorosis; a few lesions have split surfaces suggesting pustule-like eruption. Overall about 20–30% of the visible leaf area is affected. Condition appears moderate, with a mix of active and older necrotic spots. Leaf margins and veins remain largely intact, with no widespread wilting.

data.image_caption: The image shows a long, narrow leaf with distinct parallel veins and an overall medium-green color. Multiple raised, circular to irregular lesions are scattered along the blade, concentrated near the midline. Lesions are tan to orange-brown with paler centers and darker rims; individual spots range about 1–6 mm, with a few larger necrotic lesions-like patches ~8–10 mm. Surrounding tissue shows slight yellowing and localized collapse. Approximately 8–12 lesions are visible on this segment, indicating a moderate level of damage; some spots appear newer and active while others look older and partially healed.
data.question: Could you please elaborate on the specific indicators or manifestations that signify the occurrence of Rice Blast?
data.answer: Leaf Blast: Can occur throughout the growth period, with severe damage during the tillering to jointing stages. The disease presents four types of lesions based on climate and variety resistance. Chronic lesions start as dark green spots, expanding into spindle-shaped lesions with brown necrotic lines. The center is grey-white with brown edges and a yellow halo. Grey mold develops on the lesion's back, forming irregular large lesions. Acute lesions appear as dark green, near-circular or elliptical spots on susceptible varieties, with brown mold on both leaf surfaces. Under unfavorable conditions, they turn into chronic lesions. White spot lesions form small, white, near-circular spots on susceptible young leaves, which do not produce spores but can develop into acute lesions under favorable conditions. Brown spot lesions form tiny brown spots between leaf veins, mostly on highly resistant varieties or old leaves, with minimal spore production. Node Blast: Occurs post-heading, starting as brown dots on the nodes, gradually expanding around the node, turning it black and brittle. Early infections cause white heads. Neck Blast: Begins as brown dots on the neck, spreading and browning the neck, causing white heads. Late infections result in unfilled grains. Infected panicle branches or rachis lead to sterile spikelets. Grain Blast: Forms brown elliptical or irregular spots, blackening the grains. Some hulls show no symptoms, while the glumes turn brown, carrying the pathogen. Leaf Blast: Initial stages involve small, dark green lesions on the leaves.
data.reasoning: The caption provides a clear, detailed symptom description (leaf shape, parallel veins, lesion size, color gradation, distribution, lesion counts, and evidence of ageing), which is highly useful for diagnosis. However it omits the plant species and any tentative disease/pest identification, lacks context on environmental conditions or temporal progression, and gives no indication of overall plant/systemic severity or management steps. Language is professional and concise.
data.suggestions: Add the plant species (or crop), propose likely causal agents or a short differential (e.g., fungal leaf spot vs bacterial lesions), and give context (location, recent weather, irrigation, onset/timeline). State an overall severity rating and whether other plant parts are affected. Recommend next steps for confirmation (culturing, microscopy, lab tests) and practical immediate actions (sanitation, fungicide options or cultural controls) to make the caption diagnostically actionable.

data.image_caption: Plant: Rose (Rosa spp.); Probable disease: foliar pustular lesions (likely Phragmidium/Puccinia spp.). The pictured compound leaf is elongated with pinnate lobes and a central midrib; dark‑green surface bears numerous raised yellow‑orange pustules (1–2 mm) clustered along the midrib, secondary veins, leaf apex and right margin, with localized browning and chlorotic halos. Symptoms affect ~20–30% of the visible surface—moderate, active but not advanced infection. Diagnostic steps: inspect and photograph both leaf surfaces, note spore color on the underside, and collect fresh pustules for microscopy or lab confirmation. Management: remove/destroy infected leaves, improve airflow and sanitation, consider early fungicide sprays (rotate FRAC groups: triazoles, QoIs or sulfur where labeled), and consult local extension for product choice and timing.
data.question: What are the effective control measures that can be implemented to manage Tomato Leaf Mold?
data.answer:
1. **Resistant Varieties**: Use resistant varieties such as Jiafen 15, Jiafen 16, Jiafen 17, Zhongza 7, Shenfen 3, and Jiahong 15 based on local conditions.
2. **Seed Treatment**: Soak seeds in 55°C water for 30 minutes before sowing to eliminate pathogens. Rinse seeds thoroughly with clean water and air-dry before sowing.
3. **Crop Rotation**: Rotate tomatoes with cucurbits or other solanaceous vegetables every three years to reduce soil-borne pathogens.
4. **Greenhouse Disinfection**: In greenhouses where rotation is difficult, disinfect before planting by burning a mixture of 0.25 kg sulfur powder and 0.50 kg sawdust per 37 m³ of space, sealing the greenhouse for 24 hours. Alternatively, use 45% chlorothalonil smoke fumigant at 0.25 kg per 110 m² for one day.
5. **Cultivation Management**: Manage temperature and humidity in the greenhouse, ventilate appropriately, control watering, and reduce humidity after watering. During prolonged rainy periods and post-infection, limit irrigation. Use appropriate plant density, prune to enhance ventilation and light penetration, and apply balanced fertilizers, avoiding excess nitrogen. Increase phosphorus and potassium. Remove infected leaves promptly and dispose of them by deep burying or burning.
6. **High-Temperature Treatment**: On sunny days, close the greenhouse at noon to raise the temperature to 30-33°C for about 2 hours, then ventilate to lower the temperature. This method effectively controls the pathogen.
data.reasoning: The caption provides detailed, specific symptom descriptions (lesion color, size, distribution along midrib and veins, pustule-like form, percent leaf area affected) and an assessment of severity and stage. These details are highly useful for diagnosis. However, it does not identify the plant species nor propose a likely diagnosis or differential (e.g., rust or other pustular pathogen), nor does it mention diagnostic observations (underside of leaf, spores) or management recommendations, which reduces its practical utility for treatment decisions.
data.suggestions: Add the plant species or crop and a probable disease or differential diagnosis (yellow‑orange, raised pustules on veins often indicate rust fungi such as Puccinia spp.). Note whether pustules are present on the leaf underside, spore color, and any recent weather/phenology information. Provide diagnostic next steps (collect fresh pustules for microscopy or lab confirmation, take close-up photos of both leaf surfaces) and brief management advice (cultural sanitation, resistant varieties, targeted fungicide options and timing) or recommend consulting local extension services for specific treatments.
data.original_caption: The single compound leaf is elongated with pronounced pinnate lobes and a central midrib; surface texture is slightly ridged. Overall color is dark green, but there are numerous small, raised yellow-orange spots and pustule-like specks primarily clustered along the midrib, secondary veins and toward the leaf apex and right margin. Individual spots are roughly 1–2 mm in diameter. Marginal areas show localized browning and slight chlorotic halos. Symptoms are moderate in extent, affecting about 20–30% of the visible surface, suggesting an active but not yet fully advanced stage of spread.

data.image_caption: Plant: Broadleaf species. Symptoms: single elongated, pinnately lobed leaf with deep serrated margins showing numerous small (0.5–2 mm), pale yellow–off‑white speckles and tiny raised granules concentrated toward the midrib and distal half; leaf tip shows slight browning/desiccation. Spots appear superficial rather than sunken or greasy; affected area ≈10–25% of surface—mild to moderate, early–mid stage. Likely causes: sap‑feeding pests (spider mites, thrips, eriophyid mites) causing stippling, or less likely early fungal/bacterial pustules. Actions: inspect leaf underside with a 10–30× hand lens for webbing, eggs, or pustules; take close‑up photos and samples for lab diagnosis; map distribution and progression over 3–7 days. If mites/thrips confirmed, apply targeted miticide/insecticide per label; otherwise employ sanitation, remove heavily affected foliage, and delay broad fungicide use until confirmed.
data.question: Could you elaborate on the pathogen responsible for Tomato Leaf Mold and the specific conditions that favor its development?
data.answer: The disease is caused by the fungus Cladosporium fulvum Cooke from the Deuteromycetes class. The pathogen spreads through the air and infects through stomata on the underside of leaves. High temperature and humidity favor the disease, with humidity being a crucial factor. At 22°C, a water film on the leaf surface for 4 hours can trigger infection. If the greenhouse temperature is 20-25°C with over 90% relative humidity, leaf mold can develop and become severe within three days. Without control measures, it can devastate crops within a week. Low light conditions also promote the disease.
data.reasoning: The caption provides a clear, detailed description of leaf morphology and symptom characteristics (spot size, color, distribution, and percent cover), which is useful for diagnosis. However it omits the plant species and any tentative disease/pest identification, lacks comments on lesion texture (necrotic vs. chlorotic), underside symptoms, and offers no context or management recommendations. This limits its usefulness for agricultural decision‑making.
data.suggestions: State the plant species/cultivar and suggest likely causes (e.g., mite or thrips stippling, early fungal/bacterial lesions, or physiological speckling) based on symptom pattern. Note whether lesions are sunken, greasy, or powdery and check the leaf underside for webbing, eggs, or pustules. Report distribution across the plant/field and progression rate. Provide next steps: take close-up photos, examine with a hand lens or microscope, sample symptomatic tissue for lab diagnosis, and recommended short-term actions (scouting, targeted insecticide/miticide if pests found, or sanitation/fungicide if infection suspected).
data.original_caption: Single elongated, pinnately lobed leaf with deep serrated margins and a pronounced central vein. Overall color is medium to dark green with paler green veins. Numerous small, pale yellow to off-white speckles and tiny raised granules are scattered across the upper surface, mostly concentrated toward the midrib and distal half; individual spots are about 0.5–2 mm in diameter. The leaf tip shows slight browning and minor desiccation. Symptoms cover roughly 10–25% of the surface, appearing mild to moderate in severity and consistent with an early to mid-stage foliar problem.

data.image_caption: Plant: likely grass (upper/penultimate leaf at heading); Probable disease: linear yellow-orange pustules (Puccinia striiformis) — differential includes physiological/bacterial streaking but the linear, vein‑parallel chlorotic streaks with scattered orange‑brown pustule‑like uredinia strongly support a pustular lesions. Symptoms: elongated pale‑yellow to straw streaks, pustules ~1–2 mm, affecting ~30% of the visible leaf with some localized tissue collapse. Severity/development: moderate, localized in the upper canopy and actively spreading; cool, moist/dewy conditions would favor rapid advance. Recommendations: confirm by microscopy or lab PCR (look for urediniospores in linear uredinia); intensify scouting (any flag‑leaf infection at heading often warrants treatment); consider resistant varieties, timely foliar fungicide (triazole ± QoI or triazole+SDHI mixes, rotate FRAC groups), and cultural controls (reduce green bridge, optimize aeration and N).
data.question: What methods of control can be employed to manage Wheat Leaf Rust?
data.answer:
Control mainly relies on planting resistant varieties, supplemented by chemical treatments and cultural practices.
1. Plant resistant and tolerant varieties such as Shaanong 7859, Ji 5418, Lumai 1, Xiaoyan 6, Xuzhou 21 for winter wheat in the Huang-Huai-Hai region. Other recent resistant winter wheat varieties include Jingdong 1, 8, Jingke 3 (Jingke 931), Jing 411, Beinong White, Wanmai 26, 27, 28, Mianyang 26, Bainong 64, Zhoumai 9-Aoyou 688 series, Xinbaofeng (7228), Yumai 39 (Yunong 8539), Zao 5, Jinsong 49, Xingmai 17, Dianmai 19, Qinmai 12, Jimai 48, 40, Ji 92-3235, 6021 new series; spring wheat varieties include Kenjiu 5, Longmai 23, Longfu Mai 7, Mengmai 30, Jingyi 1, Longchun 8139, Dingfeng 3.
2. Chemical treatment: a) Seed dressing using 0.03%-0.04% (active ingredient) of Yerust special or 0.2% of 20% triazolone oil dressing seeds. b) Use 15% Baofeng 1 seed coating agent (active ingredients are fungicide, carbendazim, thiram, and phorate) to coat seeds which automatically cures into a film after sowing, forming a protective ring with a long-lasting effect. For every kg of seeds, use 4g of coating to excellently control wheat leaf rust, powdery mildew, and bunt, also controlling soil-borne pests. c) Spray 20% triazolone oil emulsion diluted 1000 times at the onset of the disease to also control stripe rust, stem rust, and powdery mildew; repeat every 10-20 days, 1-2 times for control.
4. Strengthen cultural control measures: Sow at the appropriate time, eliminate weeds and volunteer wheat seedlings, and ensure timely drainage during the rainy season to prevent moisture retention.
data.reasoning: The caption provides excellent, specific symptom detail (shape, color, size, distribution and severity) that is highly useful for diagnosis. However it fails to identify the host species and does not propose a likely disease or management steps. Without host identification and a probable causal agent, the caption is less actionable for agricultural decision-making.

Offer a differential diagnosis (e.g., stripe rust/puccinia vs. bacterial or physiological streaking) and justify it based on the orange‑brown pustules and parallel streaking. Add canopy distribution, progression rate, and any recent weather (cool, moist favors stripe rust). Recommend confirmatory sampling (microscopy or lab), immediate scouting thresholds, and possible interventions (resistant varieties, fungicide options and timing, cultural controls).
data.original_caption: The image shows a grassy plant with long narrow leaves and developing seed heads. A prominent central leaf displays numerous elongated pale yellow to straw colored streaks running parallel to the leaf veins, varying from fine lines to broader bands two to thirty millimeters wide and several centimeters long. Scattered within and between the streaks are small orange brown pustule like specks about one to two millimeters across. Discoloration affects roughly one third of the visible leaf surface, with some localized tissue collapse. Overall symptom severity appears moderate and actively spreading.

data.image_caption: Plant: Grass with long narrow leaves; Probable disease: pustular lesions, consistent with active uredinial sporulation. The leaf exhibits numerous small, raised orange–brown pustules and streaks arranged in linear rows parallel to the central vein; pustules elongated ~1–3 mm × <1 mm. Surrounding tissue shows faint chlorosis; 10–25% of the visible lamina is affected, indicating localized early–moderate infection likely in an active spore‑producing stage. Confirm with light microscopy for urediniospores or send to a diagnostic lab; inspect adjacent leaves and field-level incidence. Management: increase scouting (weekly), improve airflow and remove volunteer/alternate hosts, deploy resistant cultivars and balanced N, and consider timely fungicide application (systemic triazoles or QoI mixtures per label). For records, include date/location, a scale bar, and wider canopy images.
data.question: Please provide an explanation of the pathogen that causes Wheat Leaf Rust?
data.answer: The pathogen is Puccinia recondita (P. recondita Roberge ex Desmaz. f. tritici), also known as the cryptic wheat stem rust fungus. It belongs to the kingdom Fungi, subkingdom Basidiomycota, class Urediniomycetes, family Puccinaceae, genus Puccinia. Summer spores are unicellular, spherical to nearly spherical, yellow-brown, finely spiked with 6-8 scattered germination pores, measuring 18-29×17-22 (μm); winter spores are bicellular, rod-shaped, with a flat top and a short dark brown stem, measuring 39-57×15-18 (μm). Winter spores germinate to produce four small spores, infecting alternate hosts, resulting in the formation of rust bodies and sex organs. The sex organs are orange-yellow, spherical to flattened spherical, measuring 80-145μm, embedded under the host epidermis, producing orange-yellow oval sexual spores. Rust bodies form on the corresponding backside of leaf lesions, capable of producing chain-like spherical rust spores, measuring 16-26×16-20 (μm). To differentiate from wheat stripe rust, take a small amount of summer spores, add a drop of concentrated hydrochloric acid or phosphoric acid, cover with a glass slide, and inspect under a microscope; stripe rust spores will concentrate into multiple small clusters, while leaf rust concentrates into a single central cluster.
data.reasoning: The caption provides a clear, detailed symptom description—leaf shape, exact pustule color, size, arrangement in linear rows, localized distribution (10–25%), and note of active sporulation—which is highly useful for diagnosis. However, it fails to identify the host plant and does not state a probable disease (e.g., rust) or provide context (field vs single sample), management guidance, or diagnostic next steps. These omissions limit its practical usefulness for agricultural decision-making.
data.suggestions: Include the plant species or crop and state a likely diagnosis (for example: 'consistent with rust (Puccinia spp.)') while noting uncertainty. Add contextual details: whether other leaves/plants are affected, sample location/date, and environmental conditions favoring disease. Recommend diagnostic steps (microscopy or lab confirmation, inspect for uredinia/urediniospores) and actionable management options (scouting frequency, cultural controls like removing volunteers/practicing crop rotation, and chemical options such as timely fungicide application—systemic triazoles or strobilurins—following label guidance). For future images, add a scale bar or ruler and a wider shot showing plant canopy to assess incidence and severity at the field level.
data.original_caption: The image shows a single long, narrow leaf with a smooth surface and a distinct central vein. Along the midsection and slightly toward one margin there are numerous small, raised pustules and streaks, orange to brown in color, clustered in roughly linear rows parallel to the vein. Individual pustules are elongated, about one to three millimetres long and less than one millimetre wide. Surrounding tissue shows faint yellowing but the remainder of the leaf remains green. Distribution is localized to the circled mid-area, affecting roughly ten to twenty-five percent of the visible surface. Appearance suggests an active, sporulating stage.

data.image_caption: Host: unidentified broadleaf (simple, ovate leaf with serrate margin) — confirm species. Symptoms: 5–7 pale tan to off‑white lesions on the upper surface, 2–12 mm, round to irregular with some slightly sunken/desiccated centers and mild peri‑lesion discoloration; overall 10–20% leaf area affected indicating early–moderate disease. Differential: fungal leaf spots (Alternaria, Septoria, Cercospora), anthracnose, bacterial necrotic lesions (Xanthomonas/Pseudomonas) or abiotic injury. Diagnostic checks: look for concentric rings, black pycnidia/fruiting bodies, water‑soaked halos, lesions on the underside, greasy exudate, and recent wet weather correlation. Recommendations: submit a sample for lab confirmation if needed; remove infected leaves, improve airflow, avoid overhead irrigation, sanitize tools. Consider protective fungicides (chlorothalonil/mancozeb) or copper for bacterial cases—follow labels and rotate modes of action; scout weekly and treat if spread exceeds ~10% foliage.
data.question: Could you introduce the characteristic symptoms that indicate the presence of Apple Grey Spot disease?
data.answer: The pathogen overwinters as mycelium, conidiophores (plates), or ascocarps in fallen diseased leaves. In the following spring, conidia are produced after rain and spread to the tree by wind and rain, infecting leaves and causing lesions. Circular spot disease occurs earlier, with onset in late April to early May in northern China, reaching its peak 2-3 weeks later. Brown spot and grey spot diseases generally occur simultaneously in May-June, peaking in July-August, with severe damage in the fall. The diseases thrive in hot, rainy conditions and are more severe in poorly managed orchards with dense canopies and weak trees. Varieties like Guoguang, Hongyu, Qingxiangjiao, and Jinguo are more susceptible, but their resistance to the three diseases varies.
data.reasoning: The caption is clear, well‑structured, and provides detailed symptom descriptions (leaf shape, lesion color, size range, number, sunken centers, and estimated % area affected), which are useful for preliminary assessment and severity staging. However, it omits the plant species/variety and does not attempt a likely diagnosis (e.g., fungal leaf spot, bacterial spot, or abiotic injury) or mention underside symptoms, lesion margins/halos, or environmental context—information that is important for accurate identification and management.
data.suggestions: Add the host plant identification and a differential diagnosis (e.g., common leaf spot pathogens or abiotic causes). Note diagnostic details to check: presence of concentric rings, pycnidia/fruiting bodies, water‑soaked halos, lesions on the leaf underside, and progression after wet weather. Provide context (recent rain, irrigation, cultivar susceptibility) and practical next steps: sample for lab confirmation if needed, implement sanitation and improved airflow, avoid overhead irrigation, and consider targeted fungicide/bactericide options with label guidance and scouting frequency/thresholds.
data.original_caption: Single simple leaf, oval with a pointed tip and serrated margins, dark green with a prominent midrib. Several pale tan to off-white lesions are scattered across the upper surface; shapes range from round to elongated and irregular. Lesion sizes appear mostly 2–12 mm in diameter, about five to seven discrete spots, some slightly sunken or desiccated in the center. Surrounding tissue shows mild discoloration but no widespread yellowing. Overall symptom extent is low to moderate, affecting roughly 10–20% of the leaf surface; stage appears early to moderate disease development.

data.image_caption: Plant: broadleaf species (species not confirmed). Symptom: a single irregular, pale tan–cream necrotic patch (6–10 mm) located near the midrib ~1/3 from the petiole on an otherwise glossy dark‑green ovate leaf with pinnate venation; lesion has a slightly darker margin and dry, thinned tissue. No pustules, oozing, or frass visible; damage is localized (<5% leaf area), consistent with early, low‑severity necrosis. Differentials: early fungal/bacterial leaf spot, localized insect puncture, or abiotic scorch. Recommendations: photograph both leaf surfaces and whole plant with a scale, monitor weekly for spread, inspect for exudate/fruiting bodies/frass, remove affected leaves, improve airflow, avoid overhead irrigation, and submit samples for lab diagnosis if lesions increase.
data.question: What methods can be implemented to effectively control Apple Grey Spot?
data.answer:
(1) Cultivation Practices: Strengthen fertilizer and water management to enhance tree vigor; remove and burn fallen leaves and fruits.
(2) Chemical Protection: Combine with the control of fruit rot diseases and arrange chemical treatments accordingly, focusing on the proper timing of sprays. Use the same chemicals as for ring spot disease. During the young fruit stage, spray with Bordeaux mixture (zinc-copper) or use 30% Green Guard Suspension at 300-500x dilution, 70% thiophanate-methyl wettable powder at 1000x dilution, etc. During the rainy season, add a spreading agent like '6501' at 1000x dilution or other spreading agents.
data.reasoning: The caption is clear, well‑written, and provides useful, specific symptom details (shape, size, color, margin, severity estimate). It correctly avoids over‑claiming a diagnosis and notes the need for more images. However, it omits the plant species/variety and any differential diagnoses or contextual information (environment, progression), which limits its usefulness for treatment decisions.
data.suggestions: Identify the plant species/variety and include context (age, recent weather, irrigation, nearby host symptoms). Add high‑resolution closeups of both leaf surfaces, a scale bar or ruler, and photos showing whole plant and canopy. Suggest likely differentials (e.g., early fungal/bacterial lesion, insect feeding, abiotic burn) and note diagnostic signs to check (oozing, pustules, frass, lesion concentric rings). Recommend monitoring frequency, sampling for lab tests if lesions spread, and interim cultural controls (remove affected leaves, improve airflow, avoid overhead irrigation).
data.original_caption: The single broad, ovate leaf has a pointed tip and visible pinnate veins; margins appear slightly serrated. Overall leaf color is dark green with a glossy surface. Near the midrib, about one-third from the petiole, there is a single irregular, pale tan-to-cream necrotic patch roughly 6 to 10 mm across with a slightly darker margin; tissue inside the spot appears dry and thin. No other obvious lesions or pustules are visible. Damage is localized and small, estimated under 5% of the leaf area, suggesting an early, low-severity stage. Need more images for confirmation.

data.image_caption: Plant: cereal (Zea mays); leaf surface: upper. Single elongated leaf with parallel veins and pale midrib; medium‑green background with localized chlorosis, browning and slight margin curling. Numerous raised orange–brown pustules (1–3 mm) scattered singly and in clusters, concentrated mid‑to‑distal lamina; one larger tan, slightly sunken necrotic patch (~15–25 mm) with pale halo. Approximately 30% of visible area affected; active, moderate infection consistent with uredinia. Probable diagnosis: pustular lesions (Puccinia spp.—common or southern pustular lesions); differential includes pustular blights—confirm by microscopy/culture. Recommendations: add a photo scale, record recent weather/crop stage, scout every 7–10 days; if disease reaches the upper canopy during reproductive stages, consider fungicide (triazoles, QoIs or recommended azole+mixes with FRAC rotation), plant resistant hybrids, remove volunteers, and improve airflow.
data.question: Please describe the morphological features that define Corn Northern Leaf Blight?
data.answer: The pathogen, Exserohilum turcicum (Pass.) Leonard and Suggs, also known as Helminthosporium turcicum Pass. or Drechslera turcica (Pass.) Subram. & Jain, belongs to the subphylum Deuteromycotina. The conidiophores emerge from the stomata, either singly or in clusters of 2-3, brown, unbranched, straight or slightly bent, with a larger basal cell, light-colored tip, 2-8 septa, and measure 35-160 × 6-11 μm. The conidia are fusiform or long-fusiform, olive-brown, with a blunt round or long oval tip, tapering base, 2-7 septa, and measure 45-126 × 15-24 μm, with a prominent hilum extending beyond the basal cell. The sexual state, Setosphaeria turcica (Luttr.) Leonard & Suggs, also known as Trichometasphaeria turcica Luttr. or Keissleriella turcica (Luttr.) V. Arx, typically does not produce a sexual stage under natural conditions. The mature ascomata are black, elliptical to spherical, measuring 359-721 × 345-497 μm, with an outer layer of dark brown pseudoparenchyma. The ostiole is covered with many short, stiff, brown hairs. The inner layer consists of smaller transparent cells. The asci grow from the base of the ascomatal cavity, cylindrical or club-shaped, with short stalks, measuring 176-249 × 24-31 μm. Ascospores are colorless and transparent when young, turning brown when mature, spindle-shaped, mostly with three septa, constricted at the septa, and measure 42-78 × 13-17 μm.

data.question: What environmental conditions favor the development and spread of Corn Northern Leaf Blight?
data.answer: Temperatures of 20-25°C and relative humidity above 90% favor disease development. Temperatures above 25°C or below 15°C and relative humidity below 60% inhibit disease development. In spring corn regions, the disease rapidly develops during the jointing to tasseling stages under suitable temperatures and continuous rainy days, leading to epidemics. Nitrogen deficiency during the tasseling and silking stages increases disease severity. Low-lying areas, high planting density, and continuous cropping also promote disease occurrence.

Lesions concentrated on blade margins and along some veins, affecting ~25–35% of the surface. Severity: mild–moderate, early–progressing. Differential diagnosis: potassium deficiency (fits marginal chlorosis/necrosis on older tissue); salt/chemical scorch (rapid margin necrosis, especially if recent sprays or saline irrigation); drought/frost stress (edge browning and curl, check soil moisture/temperature history); vascular pathogen unlikely without necrotic streaking or wilting. Recommendations: provide whole‑plant and underside/petiole close‑ups, record recent irrigation/fertilizer/pesticide history, and perform soil and leaf nutrient and EC tests; monitor with dated photos.
data.question: What are the control strategies that can be employed to manage Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus?
data.answer:
1. Cultivating Healthy Seedlings: Preventing early infection is crucial. Remove weeds around the nursery bed and disinfect the soil to reduce pathogen sources. Use TYLCV-resistant B root irrigation agent (3000x dilution) and cover with 40-60 mesh insect-proof netting. Spray TYLCV vaccine every 5 days starting from the 2-3 leaf stage, for three applications. Use TYLCV-resistant B (2000x dilution) for root irrigation during transplanting and pre-planting.
2. Agricultural Practices: At planting, water with TYLCV-resistant B (2000-3000x dilution). After seedling establishment, spray TYLCV-resistant A (1 packet per bucket of water) every 3-4 days, for four applications. Control nitrogen fertilizer and maintain soil moisture. Apply fertilizer and water in small, frequent amounts to avoid drought and waterlogging. Ventilate to prevent high temperatures and regulate field temperature and humidity. Apply organic fertilizer to promote robust plant growth and enhance disease resistance. Spray TYLCV-resistant agent once or twice during the first and second fruit clusters. Remove weeds and plant debris to reduce insect sources. Use 40-60 mesh insect-proof netting at greenhouse vents and yellow sticky traps to prevent whitefly.
3. Treatment: If infection occurs, irrigate with TYLCV-resistant B (2000-3000x dilution) and spray TYLCV-resistant A or TYLCV vaccine every 3-4 days for 4-5 applications. Alternatively, apply TYLCV-resistant B as a drench (1000-1500 ml per acre). During treatment, avoid using growth regulators or general virus drugs. The best time for treatment is 3-4 days after watering. Two treatments can control the spread, and 3-4 treatments can restore early infected plants. For advanced infections, combine root irrigation and spraying for rapid recovery.

Efficacy of Treatment:
1. Three vaccinations during the seedling stage can achieve over 90% disease resistance.
2. Combined treatment with seedling vaccination, root irrigation, and four sprays of TYLCV-resistant agent after transplanting can achieve over 96% disease resistance.
3. Additional spraying during the first and second fruit clusters can achieve over 99% disease resistance.

Important Considerations for Treatment:
1. Root irrigation is more effective than drenching. Use 500 ml of root irrigation agent for 2000-2500 plants, mixing 6-7 ml with 30 kg of water for 30 plants. For drenching, use 2-3 bottles per acre.
2. Spray TYLCV-resistant agent or vaccine during cooler parts of the day (morning or evening) for best results. Dilute the solution twice for uniform application. Use 30-45 kg of water per acre before flowering, 45-60 kg during flowering, 60-75 kg during the first and second fruit clusters, and 120-150 kg for more than three clusters. Mix one packet of agent with 30 kg of water. Adding agricultural silicone adjuvants enhances effectiveness.
3. Reasons for treatment failure: (a) Mixing or alternating with hormone-containing foliar fertilizers or general antiviral agents, or using excessive hormone concentrations during flowering; (b) Insufficient dosage or uneven spraying; (c) Not adhering to the treatment schedule.
4. Effective treatment of TYLCV depends on correct application methods and dosages. Insufficient or uneven application will not yield satisfactory results.

data.question: Please describe the symptoms that indicate the presence of Tomato Yellow Leaf Curl Virus?
data.answer: Infected tomato plants exhibit stunted growth and may halt development. The top leaves often turn slightly yellow, become smaller, curl upward at the edges, thicken, and harden. The veins on the underside of the leaves may turn purple. Plants infected early in development show severe stunting and fail to flower or fruit properly. In later stages, only the upper leaves and new shoots show symptoms, with reduced fruit numbers and smaller, unevenly colored fruits, losing commercial value.

data.question: What are the appropriate control methods for managing Bell Pepper Bacterial Spot?
data.answer:
Crop Rotation: Rotate with non-sweet pepper, chili, cabbage, and other cruciferous vegetables for 2-3 years.
Cultivation Management: Level the land. In northern China, ridge planting is recommended, while in the south, plant on high ridges with deep trenches. Drain water promptly after rain to prevent waterlogging and avoid flooding irrigation.
Seed Disinfection: Before sowing, mix seeds with 0.3% of their weight in 50% copper oxychloride or 50% thiram wettable powder. Alternatively, soak seeds in 1% hydrochloric acid solution for 2-3 hours, then rinse with clean water before germinating and sowing.
Field Sanitation: Remove and deeply plow infected plant debris after harvest.
Chemical Control: At the onset of the disease, spray with 50% copper oxychloride wettable powder (500x dilution), 14% chelated copper solution (300x dilution), 77% kasugamycin wettable powder (400-500x dilution), 1:1:200 Bordeaux mixture, or 72% agricultural streptomycin soluble powder or streptomycin sulfate (4000x dilution). Repeat every 7-10 days, for 2-3 times.

data.question: Please elaborate on the characteristic symptoms that are indicative of Bell Pepper Bacterial Spot infection.
data.answer: Bacterial spot disease in sweet pepper occurs sporadically in fields, mainly affecting leaves. On mature leaves, initial symptoms are irregular yellow-green water-soaked spots, which later enlarge to red-brown or dark brown to rust-colored spots with a membranous texture, varying in size. During dry conditions, spots are mostly red-brown. The disease spreads quickly, with individual or multiple leaves on a plant being affected, yet the plant can still grow. In severe cases, most leaves fall off. The boundary between healthy and diseased tissue is distinct but not raised, differentiating it from pepper scab.

Severity is early–moderate with limited tissue softening. Recommendations: improve airflow and light, remove and destroy affected leaves, avoid overhead irrigation, and monitor weekly. If confirmed, treat mild infections with sulfur or potassium bicarbonate; for higher pressure use registered systemic fungicides (rotate FRAC groups) and obtain underside/close‑up photos, weather history, and lab confirmation if uncertain.
data.question: Could you provide information about the pathogen responsible for Pumpkin Powdery Mildew and its distinct disease characteristics?
data.answer: The pathogen belongs to the Oidium genus within the subphylum Eumycotina. In Southern China, the fungus spreads through asexual conidia, which act as the primary and secondary inoculants, relying on air currents to transfer between host crops in the field, completing the disease cycle without a clear overwintering phase. The fungus often produces sexual chasmothecia (appearing as tiny black specks within the powdery substance) towards the end of the growing season for surviving the summer or winter. However, in southern regions like Guangdong, the sexual stage of the fungus is rarely produced and plays an insignificant role in the disease cycle. The disease thrives in both warm, humid conditions and dry, hot weather. Comprehensive resistance investigations among varieties are still lacking. Currently, only the Phoenix pumpkin bred in Taiwan is known for its strong resistance. Other varieties such as the Jintop pumpkin from Jiangxi’s Jinggangshan, the Dourin kabocha and kabocha from Inner Mongolia, the May early pumpkin from Hubei's Xianning, the Goose-neck pumpkin from Hebei, the Box pumpkin from Jiangsu, and the Papaya pumpkin introduced in Taiwan have shown strong resilience or resistance, but further local observations and verifications are needed.

data.question: What measures can be taken for prevention and control of Pumpkin Powdery Mildew?
data.answer: Select resistant varieties which are commonly planted such as the Japanese Yixiang pumpkin, Jinchestnut pumpkin, and Orange pumpkin, and ensure pure and vigorous propagation with disease-free seedlings. For seed disinfection, sun-dry seeds for 1–2 days before planting to eliminate surface microbes and enhance germination. Soak seeds in 50°C–55°C water for 30 minutes, then continue soaking for 8–10 hours as the temperature decreases to 30°C, followed by disinfection in 1% potassium permanganate solution for 20–30 minutes. Rinse, then germinate for 48–72 hours at 28°C–30°C until sprouting occurs before planting. Manage fertilization wisely, ideally rotating with grass crops every 2–3 years. Apply 5000–7000 kg of mature farm manure per hectare, 20 kg of triple compound fertilizer, 15 kg of potassium chloride, and 5 kg of urea per hectare. Avoid fertilizing during the vine-stretching phase, and apply potassium sulfate compound fertilizer during fruit swelling, maintaining soil moisture and draining fields after rain promptly. Remove diseased, old, and yellow leaves from the base, burying them deeply or incinerating them. Improve field ventilation and light penetration to enhance plant resistance. Spray protective coatings before or at the early stage of infection using 99.1% dichlorvos at 300–500 times dilution on leaves, forming a protective layer and repeating every 5–7 days for 2–3 sessions. For chemical control, apply appropriate fungicides such as 53.8% Kasugamycin 1000 times dilution before disease onset, 10% Shigao 1500 times dilution, 40% Fuxing 8000 times dilution, 43% Pulike 5000 times dilution, 12.5% Suprotect 2000 times dilution, or 2% Kasugamine 600 times dilution by spraying every 7–10 days for 2–4 sessions. Alternatively, use a bicarbonate solution at 600 times dilution starting when 1–2 lesions appear on individual leaves, spraying every 3–4 days for 4–6 sessions. Bicarbonate not only controls diseases but also promotes growth and can increase pumpkin yield by 10–20%. When spraying, use fine nozzles to reduce leaf surface moisture.

Take action if spread exceeds ~10–20% foliage or progresses rapidly.
data.question: Please describe the symptoms that characterize Grape Leaf Bligh.
data.answer: Grape leaf blight often appears suddenly over large areas. The visual symptoms resemble those of white rot disease, with initial water-soaked dark green blight at the leaf edges. Within a day, the affected areas turn yellow-brown, with another ring of dark green blight spreading inward. This rapid spread occurs even without rain or irrigation, causing severe blight of the entire leaf. Some growers mistake this disease for white rot disease, leading to ineffective control measures. To distinguish between the two, note that white rot disease starts at a single point on the leaf tip or edge, forming large, near-circular spots with indistinct concentric rings. In contrast, leaf blight spreads from the leaf edge towards the center, affecting the entire plant. Leaves exposed to more sunlight are more severely affected, especially at the intersections of trellises facing north. Vineyards with poor soil physical and chemical properties are more prone to severe outbreaks.

Symptoms: upper‑surface view shows patchy chlorosis with prominent raised veins and multiple irregular dark‑brown to black necrotic spots and blotches (3–12 mm) that coalesce into larger dead areas; browning extends to some margin tips with small tears. Lesions are randomly distributed but concentrated centrally/distally, affecting ~30–40% of the lamina; some spots appear advanced. No obvious concentric rings, sporulation bodies, or exudate visible in the image. Likely differentials: fungal leaf spot/anthracnose, bacterial necrotic lesions, or abiotic injury (sunscald/nutrient). Recommendations: inspect upper and lower surfaces and adjacent plants, review recent weather and irrigation, collect fresh samples for microscopy/culture/PCR, remove heavily affected tissue, improve airflow and sanitation, and apply targeted bactericide or fungicide only after pathogen confirmation.
data.question: What methods of control or management can be employed to address Grape Leaf Blight?
data.answer:
1. After the rainy season, closely monitor the growth status of grape shoots. If the shoot tips are hard and bent, water is sufficient. If the young shoots are upright and soft, with large leaf edges drooping, it indicates water deficiency, and immediate irrigation is necessary. To avoid fruit cracking, do not over-irrigate at once; alternatively, use foliar spraying. 
2. After the rainy season, timely loosen the soil to prevent compaction and improve its water retention capacity. 
3. Annually apply organic fertilizers to improve soil physical and chemical properties.
data.reasoning: The caption gives a clear, well‑measured description of leaf morphology and lesion characteristics (shape, size range, color, distribution, and percent area affected), which is highly useful for symptom assessment. However it omits the host plant identification and any differential diagnosis or likely causal agents (fungal, bacterial, abiotic, or insect). It also lacks remarks about upper vs lower surfaces, presence/absence of spores/fruiting bodies, water‑soaked halos, or environmental/contextual clues that would aid diagnosis and treatment recommendations.
data.suggestions: Add the plant species/cultivar and location of the leaf (upper or lower surface). Note additional lesion details useful for diagnosis: presence of concentric rings, chlorotic halos, raised/flattened lesions, exudate or fungal sporulation (pycnidia/uresia). Provide likely differentials (e.g., fungal leaf spot/anthracnose, bacterial spot, nutrient deficiency, sunscald) and brief recommended next steps: inspect other plants, check recent weather, collect samples for microscopy/culture, and consider sanitation and targeted chemical or cultural controls once the pathogen is confirmed.
data.original_caption: The sample shows a large, roughly heart-shaped leaf with a lobed margin and prominent raised veins. Overall leaf color is yellow-green with patchy chlorosis. Multiple irregular dark-brown to black necrotic spots and blotches are scattered across both leaf halves; individual lesions range about 3–12 mm and some coalesce into larger dead areas. Browning extends to some margin tips with small tears and thinning. Lesions are randomly distributed but more concentrated toward the central and distal areas, affecting roughly 30–40% of the surface. Symptoms appear advanced in spots with general moderate damage overall.

data.image_caption: Plant: broadleaf (species not specified). Provisional diagnosis: Superficial fungal growth — evidenced by superficial, fuzzy white–gray mycelial patches 5–20 mm in diameter concentrated on the upper surface and midrib. Leaf is ovate with prominent veins and slight folding; affected tissue beneath the coating is pale green, margins intact. Distribution is patchy, covering ~20–30% of the lamina, indicating early to active colonization with light–moderate severity. Distinguishing note: angular lesions with downy sporulation typically causes water‑soaked/chlorotic lesions with underside sporulation, whereas superficial white powdery growth is predominantly upper‑surface and powdery. Recommendations: inspect adjacent foliage, improve airflow and reduce humidity, remove and destroy infected leaves, avoid overhead irrigation, and consider contact (sulfur, potassium bicarbonate) or registered systemic fungicides with FRAC rotation. Confirm diagnosis by microscopy or lab testing and include a scale/reference in future photos.
data.question: Could you provide a overview of Apple Powdery Mildew?
data.answer: The pathogen of apple powdery mildew is Podosphaera leucotricha (EII. et Ev.) Salm. from the Ascomycota subphylum, order Erysiphales. The asexual stage is Oidium sp., a fungus from the Deuteromycota subphylum. The white powdery substance on infected parts is the mycelium and conidia of the fungus. Mycelium primarily spreads on the surface of lesions, with haustoria extending into cells to absorb nutrients. In severe infections, the mycelium can penetrate into leaf tissue. Apple powdery mildew is common in apple-producing regions in China. Besides apples, it also affects pears, quinces, crabapples, and other related species, with significant damage to seedlings and certain apple varieties like Dwarf, Zhu, Hong, Yu, Guoguang, etc.
data.reasoning: The caption gives a clear, well‑worded, and detailed description of symptoms (shape, color, size, distribution, and severity), which is useful for field assessment. However, it omits the plant species and a diagnostic identification (e.g., powdery mildew vs other surface growths), and provides no contextual or actionable information for management. That limits its usefulness for agricultural diagnosis and treatment.
data.suggestions: Add the host plant species and a provisional diagnosis (e.g., powdery mildew) with a brief rationale (superficial powdery mycelium, white to gray patches). Note distinguishing features to rule out look‑alikes (downy mildew tends to be on the underside and more translucent). Include context: number/age of affected leaves, recent weather/humidity, and a scale reference in the photo. Finally, add recommended next steps: sanitation (remove affected leaves), improve air circulation, and consider targeted fungicides (sulfur, potassium bicarbonate, or registered systemic fungicides) or confirm with laboratory/microscopic examination before treatment.
data.original_caption: The image shows a single broad, ovate leaf with a slightly folded surface and prominent white veins. Large, irregular, powdery white to grayish patches form a fuzzy coating across the central upper surface and along the midrib, with individual patches roughly 5–20 mm in diameter that have begun to merge. Underneath the coating the leaf tissue appears paler green but not extensively necrotic; margins remain mostly intact. Distribution is patchy but concentrated toward the leaf center, affecting about 20–30% of the surface. Severity appears light to moderate and at an early to active colonization stage.

data.image_caption: Plant: unidentified lanceolate‑leaf species (host not confirmed). Probable Diagnosis: Superficial fungal growth — upper leaf surface shows diffuse, white–off‑white, fuzzy mycelial patches (2–25+ mm) coalescing across most of the blade. Symptom distribution suggests an established, actively sporulating infection reducing healthy green tissue; estimated 40–70% of visible leaf area affected (moderate–high severity). Distinguishing features: powdery, upper‑surface colony vs. angular lesions with downy sporulation which sporulates on the lower surface and produces greasy or angular lesions. Management: remove infected leaves, improve airflow and reduce canopy humidity, avoid excess N. Begin foliar control at first symptoms with sulfur, potassium bicarbonate, or systemic fungicides (rotate FRAC groups; follow label and reapply every 7–14 days).
data.question: Please elaborate on the symptoms that indicate the presence of Apple Powdery Mildew.?
data.answer: Powdery mildew mainly affects seedlings, buds, shoots, young leaves, flowers, and young fruits. The primary characteristic is the white powdery appearance on infected parts. Infected seedlings develop grayish-white patches on leaves and young stems, which can cause wilting, curling, browning, and death. Severely infected leaves develop dense black spots later. Infected mature trees have shriveled buds that sprout late with short internodes, narrow and stiff leaves with curled edges, and white powder covering new shoots. Infected flower buds produce deformed flowers with narrow petals and stunted growth. Infected young fruits develop white powdery spots that turn into rust spots. Infected branches have white powder, with shortened internodes and weak growth. Severely infected shoots turn brown and die.
data.reasoning: The caption gives a clear, detailed morphological description of symptoms—leaf shape, lesion texture, color, lesion sizes, distribution, and estimated severity—useful for recognizing a superficial powdery infection. However, it does not identify the host plant or provide a provisional diagnosis (e.g., powdery mildew vs. other surface deposits), nor does it mention likely causal agents, environmental context, or management implications, which limits its practical utility for diagnosis and treatment.
data.suggestions: Add the plant species or crop and offer a tentative diagnosis (e.g., powdery mildew) with key distinguishing features (upper‑surface white, fuzzy mycelium vs. downy mildew on lower surface). Note likely environmental conditions favoring the disease, estimate severity more quantitatively (percent leaf area affected), list differential diagnoses, and include basic management recommendations (sanitation, resistant varieties, fungicide options and application timing) to improve usefulness for growers.
data.original_caption: The image shows an elongated, lance-shaped leaf with a distinct central vein and slightly undulating margins; petiole and nearby stems are visible. The upper surface is largely coated with a white to off-white, powdery layer that appears fuzzy and diffuse. Patches range from small specks (2–5 mm) to larger confluent areas covering much of the blade (10–25+ mm), distributed across most of the visible leaf surface. Background foliage appears greener. Symptom extent is moderate to high, suggesting an established surface infection reducing healthy green tissue and likely lowering photosynthetic area.
